item.title: The Last Of Part 2 Remastered PC Specs And New No Return Content Revealed
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-last-of-part-2-remastered-pc-specs-and-new-no-return-content-revealed/1100-6530264/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Naughty Dog has revealed the PC specs for The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered, which launches on April 3. There are also going to be new content additions for the roguelike No Return mode.

Naughty Dog provided four PC presets: Minimum, Recommended, High, and Very High. On the low end, the game runs at 720p at 30fps and on the very high end, while the target experience is 4K resolution at 60fps. The game requires at least 16 GB of RAM, but the Very High setting requires 32 GB. As for the GPU players will need at least a Nvidia GeForce GTX 1650 / AMD Radeon RX 550XT, while the high end requires a Nvidia GeForce GTX 4080 / AMD Radeon RX 7900XT.

PC features include adjustable texture quality, LOD distance range, volumetric quality, shadow quality, ambient occlusion, and reflections quality. There is also ultrawide monitor support up to 48:9 resolutions, as well as keyboard and mouse support along with full control remapping.

For the No Return mode, there are two new characters being added, which are Bill and Marlene from the first game. Bill has a "smuggler" playstyle that allows enemies to drop a custom pump shotgun for him to equip, and he gets double rewards from drops too. While he can't dodge, he has increased defense against melee attacks. Marlene has a "risk taker" playstyle and can reroute her path in the game once per run.

There are also four new maps: Overlook, School, Streets, and Nest. While the game on PC won't require a PSN account, players can log into their accounts to gain 50 in-game points to spend on bonuses. Those who log in will also receive a new skin for Ellie, which is Jordan A. Mun's jacket from Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet.

The Last of Us Part 2 PC Specs

Minimum:

  • Performance: 720p @ 30fps
  • CPU: Intel Core i3-8100 / AMD Ryzen 3 1300x
  • GPU: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1650 / AMD Radeon RX 550XT
  • RAM: 16 GB
  • OS: Windows 10/11 version 1090 or newer
  • Storage: 150 GB SSD

Recommended:

  • Performance: 1080p @ 60fps
  • CPU: Intel Core i5-8600 / AMD Ryzen 5 3600
  • GPU: Nvidia GeForce GTX 3060 / AMD Radeon RX 5700
  • RAM: 16 GB
  • OS: Windows 10/11 version 1090 or newer
  • Storage: 150 GB SSD

High:

  • Performance: 1440 @ 60fps
  • CPU: Intel Core i7-9700X / AMD Ryzen 7 3700X
  • GPU: Nvidia GeForce GTX 3070 / AMD Radeon RX 6800
  • RAM: 16 GB
  • OS: Windows 10/11 version 1090 or newer
  • Storage: 150 GB SSD

Very High:

  • Performance: 4K @ 60fps
  • CPU: Intel Core i7-11700 / AMD Ryzen 7 5700X
  • GPU: Nvidia GeForce GTX 4080 / AMD Radeon RX 7900XT
  • RAM: 32 GB
  • OS: Windows 10/11 version 1090 or newer
  • Storage: 150 GB SSD

Disclosure: GameSpot and Fanatical are both owned by Fandom.

George Yang on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: GTA 6 Is Not In Competition With Indie Games, PlayStation Boss Says
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/gta-6-is-not-in-competition-with-indie-games-playstation-boss-says/1100-6530259/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The launch of Grand Theft Auto VI later this year--assuming it's not delayed--is poised to be a major moment in the world of video games. According to PlayStation higher-up Greg Rice, who heads up the company's independent games outreach program, GTA 6 will be a huge success that won't necessarily negatively impact smaller games.

"[GTA 6 is] going to be the best, awesome, giant game for the year, for sure," Rice told GamesRadar. "I hear a lot of the opposite of devs, worried about it sucking all the space out. 'I don't want to launch during GTA week or even month, because that's all anyone's gonna be playing.'"

Rice believes GTA 6 will be a smashing success--because of course it will--and he also believes the video game industry has matured enough to allow for other, potentially smaller games to flourish at the same time. "It's gonna be a combination of 'there will be games that will be successful around GTA time because they're totally different,' but it'll also bring a lot more people back into the ecosystem," he said.

Grand Theft Auto 6 (GTA VI) Trailer Breakdown

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Rice believes that GTA 6 being such a massive game will bring new or lapsed players to console gaming, and, as they say, a rising tide lifts all ships.

"I'm sure there's lots of gamers that [GTA 6 will be] the only thing they play," Rice said. "It'll be the opportunity to get in on the new console generation and see what else is out there. So it's definitely gonna be a big economic boost for the games industry, and will be a multiple billion-dollar title, but I don't think that it's at competition with [indie games]."

GTA 6 is set for release in Fall 2025 on PS5 and Xbox Series X|S, but Take-Two boss Strauss Zelnick has said he cannot rule out a delay. The video game industry hasn't been growing at the level some had expected in recent years following a pandemic-level boom, but the launch of GTA 6 and Switch 2 in 2025 could help turn things around.

GTA 6's first trailer debuted in December 2023, and in the 15+ months since then, Rockstar has not uttered a word about the game, and Take-Two has only spoken about it at the highest level. Fans are eagerly awaiting any more news and a trailer, but as of yet, there is no word when that might happen.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Grab Steam Deck-Verified Games Like High On Life, Ultrakill, And More For Just $7 Each
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/grab-steam-deck-verified-games-like-high-on-life-ultrakill-and-more-for-just-7-each/1100-6530255/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Spring is officially here, and Fanatical is celebrating with an excellent Build Your Own Play On The Go Elite Collection bundle. You'll get to choose your own games from a list of 21 Deck Verified titles, and the more games you bundle together, the more money you'll save. Purchase five or more games to get each for $7, three or more to get each for $7.25, or at least two games to get each for $7.50. All games are delivered as official Steam Keys, and there's no limit on how many you can pick, so you're free to add all 21 to your bundle if you want. As a bonus, you'll get a 5% off coupon for your next Fanatical purchase.

There are some impressive games to choose from, many of which regularly cost at least $20. High on Life is arguably the most popular title of the bunch, and having the chance to add it to your collection for just $7 is a great deal. Created by the folks responsible for Rick and Morty, it features a bizarre sense of humor and a unique arsenal of weapons with their own special abilities. Our High on Life review gave it a solid 7/10, and it's certainly worth a closer look as a part of this bundle.

Other notable titles include side-scrolling Metroidvanias like Haiku The Robot, Death's Gambit: Afterlife Deluxe Edition, and the Guacamelee Collection (which includes both Guacamelee and Guacamelee 2). If you're into creepy horror adventure games, The Mortuary Assistant is worth adding to your bundle, while those who prefer cheerier, cozier vibes can check out Bear's Restaurant and Critter Café. There's also 8-Bit Adventures 2, which offers a modernized take on classic pixel art console RPGs like the original Dragon Quest and Final Fantasy.

Fans of 3D action games will want to check out Ultrakill, which is a wild blend of old-school shooters like Quake and flashy action games like Devil May Cry. The game is still in Early Access, but so far, reviews are overwhelmingly positive--and since it usually costs $25, this bundle is the ideal way to grab it for cheap. Star Wars fans, meanwhile, can pick up Star Wars: Episode I: Jedi Power Battles to channel their inner Jedi. Using the Force and your trusty lightsaber, you'll be tasked with fending off hordes of droids as you fight to reclaim the Naboo Royal Palace.

There are plenty of other games to add to your Build Your Own Play On The Go Elite Collection bundle, and we've listed the full lineup of choices below. Again, every game on the list is Deck Verified, making them great fits for Valve's handheld--though you can, of course, play them on your PC or laptop as well.

Disclosure: GameSpot and Fanatical are both owned by Fandom.

Build Your Own Play On The Go - Elite Collection (Spring 2025)

  • 8-Bit Adventures 2
  • Arise: A Simple Story + Bang-On Balls: Chronicles
  • Arranger: A Role-Puzzling Adventure
  • Bear's Restaurant
  • Creatures of Ava
  • Critter Café
  • Death's Gambit: Afterlife - Deluxe Edition
  • Guacamelee Collection
  • Haiku, the Robot
  • High On Life
  • Kujlevka
  • Loddlenaut
  • Meg's Monster
  • Rustler - Complete Edition
  • Smushi Come Home
  • Star Wars: Episode I: Jedi Power Battles
  • Takara Cards
  • The Mortuary Assistant
  • Ultrakill
  • Whisker Squadron: Survivor
  • Wildmender
